newsitem.title: USA: GOLF-PGA OF AMERICA NOWS SAYS TIGER BEEN EARNING RYDER POINTS.
newsitem.headline: GOLF-PGA OF AMERICA NOWS SAYS TIGER BEEN EARNING RYDER POINTS.

text.p: Tiger Woods is already on his way to challenging for a berth on the next U.S. Ryder Cup team as the PGA of America said Wednesday it had mis-stated its own rules last week.
Woods's victory in the Las Vegas Invitational on October 6 in his fifth start as a professional boosted the 20-year-old three-time U.S. Amateur champion into 21st place in the Ryder Cup standings.

Last week, the PGA said Woods would not receive Ryder Cup points for the Las Vegas event, stating that he only became eligible for points after becoming a member of the tour, which he officially joined following Las Vegas.

PGA of America media director Julius Mason admitted Wednesday that the PGA had erred, and said a rule had been in place since 1991 to award points to any player joining the tour during a season, retroactive to his first event as a pro.
Mason said Justin Leonard had been helped by the rule in 1994, receiving 60 points retroactively.
"We haven't had a phenomenon like Tiger climb the ladder so quickly. He caught us by surprise," Mason said. "This policy has been in place since '91. It didn't just happen because of Tiger."
The top 10 finishers at each official PGA Tour event receive Ryder Cup points on a sliding scale.
Woods therefore collects points for the Las Vegas Invitational (first), Texas Open (third), B.C. Open (equal third) and Quad Cities Classic (equal fifth).
He has 125 points. Mark Brooks heads the U.S. standings with 519.75 points.
The leading 10 players after the PGA Championship next August automatically make the U.S. team, while captain Tom Kite selects two others.
Europe will defend the Ryder Cup at Valderrama, Spain, next September.
